title: Ticket #4734: Improve debugging tools for JobRouter
description:
Note: a (very) preliminary version of the condor_job_router_info tool was secretly added to 8.2.4. as ticket #4569. This ticket is for the devel series where we address the limitations and non-maintainable code issues of the preliminary version.

We've received strong feedback from OSG site admins that the job router is quite difficult to debug. We'd like to see some client tools to help analyze setups. Suggestions we've received:

  1. Have a tool which can print all the routes (with or without defaults) and warn about any syntax errors (people often forget line continuations).
  2. Have a tool which can print all jobs matching the umbrella requirements and, for each job, print the route names which match.
  3. Given a single job and a route name, determine whether the job passes the umbrella requirements, passes the route requirements, and print the changes the router would make.

To help motivate why we ask for these tools, See Bob Ball's notes from deploying the HTCondor-CE: �https://www.aglt2.org/wiki/bin/view/AGLT2/CondorCE Not all bullet-points result in bugs or work item - it should give an flavor of what a knowledgable sysadmin finds confusing.

issues brought up on review of #4569 by Alan De Smet

Things to change:
  • Implementation of the class Scheduler is duplicated in job_router_tool.cpp and schedd_main.cpp, and they are slightly different. This will likely surprise anyone updating the code in the future. There is non-obvious behavior hiding in there. The code should be unified. Perhaps an additional constructor argument triggering different behavior (if a ClassAdCollection * is passed in, don't new up a m_consumer and m_mirror, instead store the pointer and return it from GetClassAds.)
  • The tool version of Scheduler::GetClassAds only returning something for m_id==0 is magical. Perhaps instead call some sort of Scheduler::SetClassAds to set the pointer on the first instance instead of relying on the m_id being 0.
  • It looks like JobRouter::set_schedds leaks whatever Schedulers were present before. I think the old ones should be stop()ed and deleted. It also seems like a landmine for an external party to hand in newly allocated memory for JobRouter to manage. Perhaps just pass in the two param names and let JobRouter handle instantiation. Or maybe have a second JobRouter::JobRouter that takes the param names to use.
  • Scheduler::id() is unused; strike.
  • In job_router_tool's main, if read_classad_file fails, should probably exit after the message. By continuing it seems likely that the message will be overlooked and the user will get unexpected behavior.
  • job_router_tool's main, checking !job_files.isEmpty() before iterating over it seems unnecessary. Shouldn't it merrily iterate 0 times?
  • class CondorQClassAdFileParseHelper is duplicated 3 times with minor variations: src/condor_q.V6/queue.cpp,src/condor_utils/compat_classad.cpp, src/condor_job_router/job_router_tool.cpp. (It's called CondorClassAdFileParseHelper in compat_classad.cpp) They should be unified as much as possible. (Perhaps adding sub-classes to handle any necessary differences?) The same goes for the function read_classad_file() duplicated in src/condor_q.V6/queue.cpp and src/condor_job_router/job_router_tool.cpp.
  • class JobLogMirror in job_router_tool.cpp appears to be unused. Strike.

Other things to consider:

  • JobRouter::dump_routes: Consider using the iterator interface (m_routes->begin()/end()) as more robust, just in case someone later adds an inner loop over the routes.
  • JobRouter::dump_routes: Consider looking up Universe string when writing TargetUniverse.
  • JobRouter::dump_routes: Why is CurrentRoutedJobs not reported?
  • JobRouter::~JobRouter: Do we want to stop() the scheduler objects if m_operate_as_tool? What does Scheduler::stop do?
  • job_router_tool.cpp my_exit: Seems unnecessary to flush stdout/err. Do we have systems where stdout/err don't get auto-flushed on exit?
  • job_router_tool.cpp usage: Seems silly to rely on tabstops; why not space indent?
  • job_router_tool.cpp: Why replace the default dprintf behavior? Why discard early dprintf messages (dprintf_set_output_intercept)?

Future work:

  • Expunge the disabled part of #if 1 in Scheduler.h
  • Should Scheduler::~Scheduler call m_mirror->stop() and eliminate Scheduler::stop to reduce possibilities of mis-use.
  • submit_job.cpp and job_router_tool.cpp duplicate a bunch of functions: claim_job, yield_job, submit_job, push_dirty_attributes, push_classad_diff, finalize_job, remove_job, Write*EventToUserLog, Initialize*Event, and EmailTerminate Event. The job_route_tool.cpp are simple stubs. Perhaps this would be more cleanly expressed by moving the functions into a pure virtual class, then letting the two files implement overrides. It would be more verbose, but would make the intent more obvious and provide more specific error messages if a function was added to one but not the other.
  • JobRouterHookMgr's implementation is duplicated between JobRouterHookMgr and job_router_tool.cpp. job_router_tool.cpp's version is basically all stubs. Perhaps move the interface and any shared functionality into a parent class, give each case it's own child class, then either pass in the specific child class into JobRouter::init, or have an option to JobRouter::init that selects which one to new into existance.
